Fig. 1 The XRD spectra of LayCo1Ox catalyst. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 TEM and the EDX mapping images of La0.25Co1Ox. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of LayCo1Ox catalysts. (a) Co3O4, (b) La0.11Co1Ox, (c) La0.25Co1Ox, (d) La0.42Co1Ox, (e) La0.66Co1Ox, and (f) La2O3. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (a) Co 2p XPS spectra, and (b) the relationship for surface Co at% and Co3+/Co2+ atomic ratio versus different catalysts. (c) O1s XPS spectra, and (d) the relationship between Oads/Olatt ratio and La contents. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Catalytic performances of LayCo1Ox. Reaction condition: benzyl alcohol 28.8 mmol, LayCo1Ox catalyst 100 mg, oxygen pressure 1.0 MPa, 120 °C for 8 h. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Effects of reaction conditions on the catalytic performances, (a) reaction temperature, (b) catalysts dosage, (c) oxygen pressure, and (d) reaction time. Reaction conditions: benzyl alcohol 28.8 mmol, La0.25Co1Ox catalyst 100 mg, O2 pressure 1.0 MPa, reaction temperature 120 °C, 1000 rpm, 8 h. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Time-conversion plots at various temperatures for (a) La0.25Co1Ox, (b) Co3O4, (c) La2O3, and (d) Arrhenius plots for oxidation of benzyl alcohol. Reaction conditions: benzyl alcohol 3.0 mL, La0.25Co1Ox catalyst 100 mg, O2 pressure 1.0 MPa, reaction temperature 80–120 °C, 1000 rpm, 10 h. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 (a) The hot filtration experiment and (b) stability of the catalyst. College of Chemistry & Chemical Engineering, Shaanxi Key Laboratory of Chemical Additives for Industry, Shaanxi University of Science & Technology Xi’an Shaanxi 710021 China It is desirable but challenging to explore non-noble metal based catalyst for the solvent-free aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde. LayCo1Ox was prepared through a co-precipitation method, which exhibited excellent catalytic performance for titled reaction with a yield of 73.1% and selectivity of 99.6%. Introduction of La in the Co3O4 can modify the electronic property of Co, improving the surface Co3+ content and enhancing the activity. The synergistic effects of La and Co in the bimetallic catalysts are kinetically discussed. In addition, the kinetic and experimental studies revealed that the generated water favors the selectivity but suppresses the activity for the titled reaction. It is found that good activity and excellent selectivity for the (heterocyclic)aromatic alcohols aerobic selective oxidation over the bimetallic catalyst were obtained. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Benzyl alcohol Benzaldehyde Aerobic oxidation Solvent-free La-Co bimetallic catalyst Kinetic 1 Introduction Benzaldehyde is an important chemicals, which is widely used in pesticides, medicine, dyes and daily chemicals [1]. Industrially, benzaldehyde is mainly prepared by the toluene chlorination hydrolysis method [2]. This method faces the chlorine contamination that limits its widespread being used and brings out of acidic wastes, which lead to the environmental issues. So, it is desirable to explore a greener and more economical route for production of benzaldehyde. Aerobic selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol in the liquid phase by heterogeneous catalysis is one of the attractive alternative processes. In recent years, catalysts with transition metals as the active sites have been widely studied for the selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol, such as Fe [3], Co [4], Cu [5], Mn [6,7], Pt [8], Ru [9], Pd [10], Au [11], and Ag [12]. This traditional catalytic reaction systems require solvents, such as cyclohexane [13], p-xylene [14], toluene [15,16], H2O [17], methanol [18], and acetonitrile [19]. However, the presence of solvents increases the cost of product separation and may involve the environmental pollution. Therefore, it is attractive to develop solvent-free aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol method with highly efficient catalytic performance. Several catalysts for selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol under solvent-free condition have been developed, such as Fe3O4/MPA–PHEA-Cr [20], Au-Pd/TiO2 [21], SnOx @Au-Pd [1], and CoFe2O4 NPs [22]. In these process, tert-butyl hydroperoxide, H2O2, and molecular oxygen (O2) were employed as oxidants. Among them, O2 is believed to the green oxidant for the potential application due to its low cost, non-toxicity, and easy availability. The Pd based [23], Au based [24], and Pd-Au based catalysts [25] have been applied for the titled reaction with O2 as an oxidant. However, the application of precious metals is limited by their high price and scarcity. Thus, it is attractive and urgent to explore highly efficient non-noble metal based catalyst. Nevertheless, there are few literatures regarding the non-noble metal catalysts due to its low activity [26,27] or low selectivity [28]. Therefore, it is desirable but challenging to explore non-noble metal based catalyst with both high activity and selectivity for the aerobic selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde. Bimetallic and trimetallic catalysts are usually adopted to improve the catalytic performance [29]. With the existent of the synergetic effect, bimetallic catalyst is often acceptable due to the superior catalytic performance to the monometallic catalysts. Co based catalyst is believed to have excellent catalytic performance for the oxidation reactions. In the present work, the Co3O4 was employed as a fundamental catalyst to prepare a La-Co bimetallic catalyst of LayCo1Ox. The as-prepared catalyst was investigated for the aerobic selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol under the solvent-free conditions. It showed excellent catalytic performance which is the highest among the reported non-noble metal based catalytic reaction system. To further reveal the nature of the high catalytic performance, the synergistic effects of La and Co in the bimetallic catalysts are investigated from the kinetic aspect. In addition, the kinetic and experimental studies revealed that the generated water favors the selectivity but suppresses the activity for the titled reaction. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials La(NO3)3.6 H2O, Co(NO3)2.6 H2O, ethylene glycol, and ethanol (99.98%) were obtained from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Urea was obtained from Macklin Chemical Company. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The Co-La bimetallic catalyst was prepared by a co-precipitation method. In a general procedure, The Co(NO3)2 ethylene glycol solution (0.5 mmol in 50 mL) and La(NO3)3 ethylene glycol solution (50 mL) were mixed together under a continuous stirring. Followed, 15 g urea was added into the mixture. After stirring at 160 °C for 10 h, the mixture was filtered and washed by ethanol. Subsequently, the obtained solid was heated to 600 °C with a heating rate of 1 °C/min and kept at 600 °C for 4 h. Similarly, catalysts with a varied La/Co molar ratio of 0.11, 0.25, 0.42, and 0.66 were also prepared by varying the quantity of lanthanum nitrate. The obtained catalyst was denoted as LayCo1Ox. 2.3 Catalytic performance Benzyl alcohol (28.8 mmol, 3.0 mL) and catalyst (0.100 g) were added into an autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and purged three times with 0.1 MPa O2. At the room temperature, the autoclave was filled with 1.0 MPa O2. Then, the reaction was conducted at 120 °C for 10 h. Concentrations of benzaldehyde and benzyl alcohol were determined by a HPLC (YILITE LC 3000–2 series instrument) using an Ultimate MBC18 (250 mm × 4.60 mm) column by UV detector at 254 nm wavelength (Fig. S1). The mobile phase consisted of a methanol/water solution 25/75 (V/V) fed at a flow-rate of 1.0 mL/min. The yield and selectivity of the benzaldehyde were calculated according to the formula: (1) Yield of benzaldehyde = mmol of benzaldehyde mmol of initial benzyl alcohol × 100 % (2) Selectivity of benzaldehyde = mmol of benzaldehyde mmol of reacted benzyl alcohol × 100 % 2.4 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku Ⅳ) was employed to anaḍlyse the crystal structure. It was operated with Cu Kα radiation at 40 kV and 40 mA. The scanning mode is 2 theta/theta with the scanning rate of 3°/min and it is scanned from 6° to 80°. Specific surface area was obtained on Gemini Ⅶ 2.00 by the adsorption of nitrogen at − 196 °C. The XPS spectra was obtained from ESCALAB 250Xi (Thermo Fisher) at 15 kV and 8 mA. It was calibrated with the binding energy of 284.8 eV. Casa XPS software was employed to deconvolute the asymmetrical peaks. SEM (Hitachi S-4800) was employed to analyse the morphology, which was conducted at 20 kV and 15 mA. JEM-2100 was employed to obtain the TEM images which was operated at 200 kV. La and Co contents were measured by inductive coupled plasma emission spectrometer (ICP-MS). 2.5 Catalyst recycling After each oxidation reaction, the reaction solution was centrifuged to obtain the used catalyst. Followed, the used catalyst was washed with water and methanol for several times. Then, it was dried at 80 °C. The obtained catalyst was employed in the next oxidation reaction under the same reaction conditions. 2.6 Kinetic study As a continuous reaction: Substrate → k 1 Intermediate → k 2 Product k 1 and k 2 are the rate constants. The concentration of the intermediate is time-dependence, which can be calculated according the Eq. (3) when the both step are the first order reaction. It is known that the intermediate can reach a maximum yield at a given time. When the reaction rate of d[intermediate]/dt equals to zero, the concentration of the intermediate reaches the highest. The maximum concentration of the intermediate (c max) and the corresponding time (t max) can be calculated according Eqs. (4) and (5) [30,31]. The maximum yield of the intermediate (Yield max) and selectivity (Selectivity max) can be calculated with the c max by Eqs. (1) and (2) in Section 2.3. (3) c intermediate = c 0 k 1 k 2 − k 1 ( e − k 1 t − e − k 2 t ) (4) c max = c 0 k 1 k 2 k 2 k 2 − k 1 (5) t max = ln ( k 1 / k 2 ) k 1 − k 2 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The crystal structures of catalyst were investigated by XRD characterization ( Fig. 1). The monometallic Co3O4 is presented in a cubic phase. The La oxide in the LayCo1Ox could not be observed by the XRD pattern after the La is introduced into Co3O4, which is contributed to the low content and high dispersion. Co3O4 and LayCo1Ox exhibit the similar diffraction peaks at 19.0, 31.3, 36.8, 44.8, 59.4, and 65.3° which are attributed to (111), (220), (311), (400), (511), and (440) lattice planes, respectively. Aggregated spherical particle morphology of the prepared samples can be observed from the SEM images (Fig. S2). With an increase of the La content, the morphology of La-Co bimetallic catalyst shows little change. TEM images of La0.25Co1Ox are shown in Fig. 2. It can be observed that the nanoparticle sizes range from 2 to 50 nm. The lattice spacing of 4.53, 2.44, and 2.86 Å in TEM image is indexed to (111), (311), and (220) planes of Co3O4 [32], respectively. The lattice spacing of 1.96 Å is ascribed to (110) planes of La2O3, which confirms the existence of La oxide in the bimetallic catalyst. Furthermore, the dispersion of the elemental La, Co, and O obtained by the energy dispersive X-ray spectrometry. It can be found that the elemental La and Co are highly dispersed in the catalyst (Fig. 2). Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms are employed to analyse the surface areas. As shown in Fig. 3, Co3O4, La2O3, and La-Co bimetallic catalysts show the typical type IV adsorption-desorption isotherm with a hysteresis loop-type H3 according to the IUPAC classification, implying the mesoporous structures existence. [33,34] Textural parameters of the as-prepared catalyst are listed in Table 1. Co3O4 and La2O3 have the similar surface area of approximately 34 m2·g−1. With the La oxide introduced in the Co3O4, the surface area decreases to 17 m2·g−1 in La0.11Co1Ox but it increases to 61 m2·g−1 in La0.25Co1Ox. With further increase of the La oxide content, the surface area decreases, resulting in the highest surface area for La0.25Co1Ox. The surface chemical environment of Co-La bimetallic catalysts is investigated by XPS. As shown in Fig. 4a, Co3+ and Co2+ species can be recognized by the deconvolution of Co 2p3/2 peak, corresponding to two peaks at 779.3–779.8 eV and 780.6–780.9 eV, respectively [35]. The surface Co atom percentage and Co3+/Co2+ molar ratio are estimated (Fig. 4b). Co3+/Co2+ atomic ratio on the surface of Co3O4 is 1.15. With the La introduced, the Co atomic content and the Co3+/Co2+ molar ratio on the surface first increase and then decrease, leading the highest Co3+/Co2+ ratio of 1.58 for La0.25Co1Ox. It is reported that the Co3+ contributes to the oxidation catalytic activity [36]. Therefore, La0.25Co1Ox with the most surface Co3+ is expected to have the best catalytic activity. Experimentally, the trend in the molar ratio of Co3+/Co2+ is similar to that of catalytic activity (Fig. 4b), which confirms that high catalytic activity performance is related to the Co3+ content on the surface. As shown in Fig. 4c, three peaks of O1s at 529.5, 531.2, and 533.2 eV can be obtained by deconvolution, which are recognized as lattice oxygen (Olatt), adsorbed oxygen (Oads), and adsorbed water or hydroxyl species (Ow), respectively [37,38]. The Oads/Olatt ratio in La0.25Co1Ox is the highest (Fig. 4d), indicating that La0.25Co1Ox catalyst surface can adsorb a large amount of oxygen so that the high catalytic activity is expected, which is experimentally consistent with the yield. These indicate that the introduction of La in the Co3O4 can modify the electronic property of Co, improving surface Co3+ content, consequently enhancing the catalytic activity. 3.2 Catalytic performance LayCo1Ox was employed to investigate the catalytic performance on oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde under solvent-free aerobic conditions were investigated. It can be found that benzyl alcohol can be exclusively transformed to benzaldehyde with a yield of 63.7% over Co3O4 ( Fig. 5). The activity of La2O3 is relatively higher with a conversion of 84.7% as compared with that of Co3O4 and La0.25Co1Ox, but with a lower selectivity of 55.4%. When the La is introduced in the Co3O4, the activity of LayCo1Ox increases first and then decreases while the selectivity unchanges at 99.5%, giving the highest yield of 73.1% over La0.25Co1Ox. On one hand, both of La2O3 and Co3O4 have the catalytic activity, implying both La and Co are the active sites in LayCo1Ox catalyst. Therefore, La acts as a co-catalyst to improve the activity but not declines the selectivity. On the other hand, the oxidation state of Co2+ and Co3+ are slightly decreased (Fig. 4a) when La3+ doped in the Co3O4 spinel structure formed LayCo1Ox catalyst, contributing the lattice oxygen in LayCo1Ox tended to attract fewer electrons from its adjacent Co cations to balance its excess electrons due to the presence of La3+ [39]. Therefore, the doped La in Co3O4 is the co-catalyst but it can also modify the electronic properties of Co to improve the catalytic performance. The effects of the reaction temperature on titled reaction were investigated over La0.25Co1Ox catalyst. As shown in Fig. 6a, the benzaldehyde is the exclusive product and the activity enhances when the temperature ranges from 80° to 120°C. But the conversion of benzyl alcohol decreases when the temperature is higher than 130 °C. A decrease of oxygen solubility with an increase of temperature results in a decline of the reaction rate, which subsequently contributes to a decrease of the conversion. The influence of catalyst amount on the oxidation reaction was conducted. As shown in Fig. 6b, there is low conversion without adding a catalyst, indicating La0.25Co1Ox provides the active sites for the catalytic reaction. The conversion of benzyl alcohol is improved from 44.5% to 73.4% when the amount of the catalyst increases from 50 to 100 mg. This is because the number of available active sites increases when the dosage of the catalyst increases. However, few changes of the activity are observed with further increase in the catalyst loading. The selectivity to benzaldehyde first increases and then gradually decreases with a threshold of 100 mg for the catalyst amount. The influence of the oxygen pressure was studied (Fig. 6c). Without oxygen, the oxidation reaction does not occur, implying that La0.25Co1Ox catalyst could not directly oxidize benzyl alcohol and the oxygen is essential for the reaction. The conversion of benzyl alcohol increases by elevating the pressure from 0.1 to 1.0 MPa. When the pressure is higher than 1.0 MPa, there is no obviously change in the conversion. The oxygen solubility can be enhanced with a higher pressure, leading to a higher oxygen coverage on the catalyst and improving the oxidation rate. Therefore, the optimum pressure is 1.0 MPa. It can be found that the selectivity changes little with the exclusive product of benzaldehyde (Fig. 6d). The conversion increases gradually from 4 to 8 h. But the conversion increases very slowly with the time prolongs after 8 h, which is attributed to the reaction equilibrium by literature [40]. However, the selectivity is gradually decreased after 12 h due to the by-product of benzoic acid produced. Therefore, the reaction does not reach equilibrium because the reaction still continues and the product distribution is changed with time. Actually, water can be generated during the reaction process under the solvent-free condition. Therefore, it can be postulated that the formed water is more easily adsorbed on the surface because the existence of surface hydroxyl species (Ow). Consequently, the active sites are occupied by generated water, which results in a decrease of substrates adsorption. Therefore, the reaction rate slows down and the conversion increases very slowly. To confirm the postulated hypothesis, several controlled experiments were conducted ( Table 2). When 200 µL water is added into the solvent-free system, the conversion decreases from 73.4% to 70.3% (Table 2, entries 1 and 2). Moreover, when the reaction is carried out in the water solvent for 24 h, the conversion deceased from 76.5% to 64.8% (Table 2, entries 3 and 5). These confirms that water suppresses the activity by competitive adsorption on the catalyst surface. Moreover, when the molecular sieve is employed as the generated water remover, the conversion can be improved from 76.5% to 90.1% (Table 2, entries 3 and 4). This further proves the generated water during the reaction disfavors the activity. In addition, the formed water can be easily adsorbed on the surface, resulting in a water film surrounds the catalyst [41]. The solubility of benzyl alcohol in water is greater than that of benzaldehyde. These make the formed benzaldehyde can be immediately abstracted into the bulk organic phase (benzyl alcohol phase) from the water layer of catalyst surface, which contributes to the easy desorption of generated benzaldehyde and reduced the re-adsorption of benzaldehyde ( Scheme 1). Therefore, high selectivity is obtained. These can be proved by the fact that the selectivity is not changed by adding water or carrying out the reaction in the water solvent (Table 2, entries 1–3 and 5). Moreover, these phenomenon can also be found over the La2O3 and Co3O4 catalyst as well as different substrates (Table S1). Therefore, the generated water favors the selectivity but disfavors the activity. Additionally, it is worth noting that it is difficult to simultaneously achieve both high activity and selectivity by the non-noble metal based catalyst for the aerobic selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde under solvent-free condition (Table S2). This work presents both high activity and selectivity for the titled reaction and is highest among the reported non-noble metal based catalysts and better than that of the most reported noble metal based catalysts. 3.3 Kinetic study of oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde Oxidation of benzyl alcohol is a two steps consecutive reaction due to that benzyl alcohol and benzoic acid can be observed. The reaction orders of the two steps can be obtained via the kinetic curve derived from the oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde and the oxidation of benzaldehyde to benzoic acid. It is found that both of them are a first order reaction revealed by experiments (Fig. S3). Image 1 Under the reaction condition, the values of rate constant k 1 and k 2 for benzyl alcohol oxidation and benzaldehyde oxidation are 0.1165 h−1 and 0.0105 h−1, respectively. It can be found that k 2 is much less than k 1, which implies that oxidation of benzaldehyde is kinetically more difficult than oxidation of benzyl alcohol under the present solvent-free conditions. This kinetically contributes to a high selectivity to benzaldehyde. To kinetically illustrate the effect of La oxide in La0.25Co1Ox on the catalytic performance, the apparent activation energies (E a) over La0.25Co1Ox, Co3O4, and La2O3 are calculated from the Arrhenius plots ( Fig. 7). The E a value over Co3O4 is 45.1 kJ·mol−1 while it is 29.4 kJ·mol−1 over La2O3, indicating La2O3 is more active for the titled reaction. After La is introduced, the E a value over La0.25Co1Ox is reduced to 35.1 kJ·mol−1, which is comparable with the reported values over transition metal catalysts for selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol [42–44]. This implies that the rate constant is improved over La0.25Co1Ox catalyst compared with that of bare Co3O4, which is consistent with the experiment observation of increased conversion in Fig. 5. The conversion of benzyl alcohol can be calculated according to Eq. (6) while the reaction time for the maximum yield can be obtained according to Eq. (7) [31]. It can be observed from Eq. (6) that the conversion is only related to k 1, indicating that highly catalytic activity can be achieved by the large k 1. The selectivity to benzaldehyde can be improved according to the Eq. (9) by increase k 1 and decrease k 2 from the kinetic view. According to the equations, the maximum yield and the corresponding conversion, selectivity, and reaction time can be calculated (Table 2, entry 6). It can be found that the calculated conversion of 92.9% at 22.7 h is greatly higher than the experimental conversion of 76.5% at 24 h (Table 2, entries 3 and 6). According to this fact, it can be inferred that the k 1 is not constant but gradually decreases under the experimental condition because the conversion is only relied on the k 1. The rate constant is related to the nature of the catalyst. As mentioned above, the quantities of active sites on the catalyst are decreased because of the competitive adsorption of generated water on the surface of the catalyst. When molecular sieves as the water remover adds into the reaction, the calculated activity is consistent with experiments (Table 2, entries 4 and 6). This kinetically confirms that the formed water adsorbed on the catalyst surface disfavors the activity. However, the selectivity changed little with or without the water remover added, which indicates that the k 2 is also affected by the competitive adsorption of water because the selectivity is related to the k 1 and k 2 according to the Eq. (9). Therefore, the oxidation of benzaldehyde is also influenced by the generated water due to the competitive adsorption on the surface of catalyst. (6) Conversion benzyl alcohol = 1 − e − k 1 t (7) Time max = ln ( k 1 / k 2 ) k 1 − k 2 (8) Yield max = k 1 k 2 k 2 k 2 − k 1 (9) Selectivity max = k 1 k 2 k 2 k 2 − k 1 1 − e − k 1 t Based on above, the reaction mechanism can be briefly described as following (Scheme 1). The reaction is occurred at the solvent-free condition with the substrate of benzyl alcohol as the solvent. At first, generated water is competitively adsorped on the surface of the catalyst, leading the adsorption of benzyl alcohol decreased, consequently the reaction rate gradually reduced. As the reaction goes on, the generated water covers the surface of the catalyst, forming the water layer around the catalyst. The water film can suppress the adsorption of benzyl alcohol and benzaldehyde, leading the activity decreases. Due the solubility of benzyl alcohol is higher than that of benzaldehyde, the generated benzaldehyde can be easily abstracted to the bulk organic phase and the re-adsorption of benzaldehyde is hard. This contributes the oxidation of benzaldehyde kinetically decreased, giving the k 2 is greatly less than k 1, consequently, achieving the high selectivity. 3.4 Stability of the catalyst To evaluate the catalytic stability of La0.25Co1Ox, hot filtration experiment was carried out (Fig. 8a). It can be observed that the yield of benzaldehyde does not change after the La0.25Co1Ox catalyst is hot filtrated, implying that the catalyst is performed in a true heterogeneous way. The stability of the catalyst is vital from the aspect of industrial application. The recyclability of La0.25Co1Ox catalyst is evaluated and the results are shown in Fig. 8b. It is found that there is no loss in conversion and selectivity after eight cycles. In addition, the La/Co molar ratio and the XRD pattern are not changed in the used La0.25Co1Ox catalyst (Table 1 and Fig. 1). These indicate La0.25Co1Ox catalyst is stable under the reaction conditions. 3.5 Oxidation of other alcohols La0.25Co1Ox catalyst is employed to examine the generality of catalytic performance for oxidation of other alcohols. As shown in Table 3, it can be found that substituted groups on the benzene ring affect the oxidation efficiency. Taking methyl benzaldehyde as an example, o-CH3 benzyl alcohol shows the lowest yield, m-CH3 benzyl alcohol has a middle yield while the p-CH3 benzyl alcohol gives the highest yield (Tables 3, a1-a3). This implies that the position of the substituted group influences the yield of aldehyde and the yield orders are p-substituted > m-substituted > o-substituted. This trend can be further proved by the o,m,p-OCH3 benzaldehyde (Table 3, a4-a6), o,m,p-OH benzaldehyde (Table 3, a7-a9), o,p-NH2 benzaldehyde (Table 3, a12-a13), o,m,p-Cl benzaldehyde (Tables 3, b2-b4). Moreover, it can be found that the electron-withdrawing group substituted benzyl alcohol has a lower yield of aldehyde than that of electron-donating group, which is consisted with literatures [38]. Besides, the catalytic system also can be employed for the oxidation of heterocyclic aromatic alcohols with the acceptable yield of aldehyde (Tables 3, c1-c7). The steric effect is observed for oxidation of substituted benzyl alcohol (Tables 3, e1 and e2). The catalyst also has an acceptable selective oxidation of aliphatic alcohol (Tables 3, f1). However, the catalytic ability is almost disappeared with aliphatic chain is higher than n-butyl alcohol (Tables 3, f2 and f3). 4 Conclusions La-Co bimetallic catalysts of LayCo1Ox were synthesized and applied for the solvent-free aerobic selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde with high activity and selectivity. It is found that the benzyl alcohol is kinetically easier to be oxidized than that of benzaldehyde over the LayCo1Ox catalyst under the solvent-free conditions, which kinetically contributes to the high selectivity. Introduction of La into Co3O4 can increase the Co3+ content and kinetically improve the catalytic activity. The formed water during the reaction process is found to suppress the activity but favors the selectivity. Moreover, the catalyst is stable under the reaction condition and can be used several times with no loss of selectivity and activity. Benzyl alcohol derivatives can be selectively oxidized with satisfied yield. More interesting, acceptable yield of aldehyde can be obtained over heterocylic aromatic alcohols. The presented LayCo1Ox catalyst is promising for industrial application. coredata.dc:description: It is desirable but challenging to explore non-noble metal based catalyst for the solvent-free aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde. LayCo1Ox was prepared through a co-precipitation method, which exhibited excellent catalytic performance for titled reaction with a yield of 73.1% and selectivity of 99.6%. Introduction of La in the Co3O4 can modify the electronic property of Co, improving the surface Co3+ content and enhancing the activity. The synergistic effects of La and Co in the bimetallic catalysts are kinetically discussed. In addition, the kinetic and experimental studies revealed that the generated water favors the selectivity but suppresses the activity for the titled reaction. It is found that good activity and excellent selectivity for the (heterocyclic)aromatic alcohols aerobic selective oxidation over the bimetallic catalyst were obtained.
coredata.dc:title: Solvent-free aerobic selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol over La-Co bimetallic catalyst: A kinetic study
